0D340BB53E974140ACBC5BEE15C25851.description: the Universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old

9274235F64594CABAC418A51A5597C58.description: the Universe expanded from a single point of high density and temperature

9A89C6EA3F1E40C19928C5CF36EE2170.description: Know that the Milky Way is one of many billions of galaxies making up the Universe and that the diameter of the Milky Way is approximately 100000 light-years

15A90B5C989A496298FA55BDC4CFA76E.description: other stars that make up the Milky Way are much further away from the Earth than the Sun is from the Earth

6FC7ECDF4D7B47ADA05B2973FAFABEE0.description: the Sun is a star in the galaxy known as the Milky Way

12B34B675B2646ACB4846BDC682B6BB1.description: galaxies are each made up of many billions of stars

AAE8182AE1F248DFB131A0DE641F06E3.description: Know that the nebula from a supernova may form new stars with orbiting planets

94DA8AB06D64431782F1E8050CAD0582.description: a very large mass star: red supergiant → supernova → black hole

32A19A05A32E4CCE826A4386EFA3166F.description: a large mass star: red supergiant → supernova → neutron star

5ABFAE4512564E1391FB700A19BFF8EE.description: a small mass star about the same mass as the Sun): red giant → white dwarf + planetary nebula

723C412A340E4D20915157F7BB09CB5E.description: Know that the next stages of the life cycle of a star depend on its mass, limited to:

88A5CA7D0C66463FA76AA807145D4837.description: Know that stable stars are formed as protostars from interstellar clouds of gas and dust due to gravitational attraction

7D3DB5BD00524842833FC84F0599302E.description: Know that stars are powered by nuclear reactions that release energy and that in stable stars the nuclear reactions involve the fusion of hydrogen into helium

9358593FD39B44AD894176CD7CFF911D.description: Know that the strength of the Sun's gravitational field decreases and that the orbital speeds of the planets decrease as the distance from the Sun increases

D6EFDB8EA2D044AF8BC8FF4704C7E553.description:
Define orbital speed from the equation:
v = 2πr / T
where r is the radius of the orbit and T is the orbital period; recall and use this equation

AC93A148B5E741CCA943C31DED7E6AC6.description: Know that the Sun is a star of medium size, consisting mostly of hydrogen and helium, and that it radiates most of its energy in the infrared, visible and ultraviolet regions of the electromagnetic spectrum

C8A5FEA3D44744D7803326EF4F263F96.description: Know that the force that keeps an object in orbit around the Sun is due to the gravitational attraction of the Sun

9B53417118F044D39BF62F0C5A8992FF.description: Know that the Sun contains most of the mass of the Solar System and this explains why the planets orbit the Sun

A29B98141D564496B835AB2F24FB7055.description: astronomical distances can be measured in light-years, where one light-year is the distance travelled in (the vacuum of) space by light in one year

A1DCA1702C1A4DE08207E254ECA886CC.description: the Sun is the closest star to the Earth

2BCC68F03A9343148799BB685D19D745.description: minor planets that orbit the Sun, including dwarf planets such as Pluto and asteroids in the asteroid belt

59C37CE2968C41689FF28897EE9BE0CF.description: the eight named planets and know their order from the Sun

E2B8F6B2B00E477EA7D67D7A5969FEF3.description: measuring and controlling thicknesses of materials with the choice of radiations used linked to penetration and absorption

0FA77DF1C5D2402CB02D711B7EF7CA25.description: sterilisation of equipment using gamma rays

45B566099C974658BA2D3720866F0CE8.description: Know the following applications of radioactivity:

9D6EE61B415543288B0E0F67226FF7E6.description: Define the half-life of a particular isotope as the time taken for half the nuclei of that isotope in any sample to decay; recall and use this definition in simple calculations, which might involve information in tables or decay curves (calculations will not include background radiation)

9AB2A11E525047B78292EB5375F76C15.description: Use decay equations, using nuclide notation, to show the emission of α-particles, β-particles and γ-radiation

985115F488254EA8BAFF45B7381D42FA.description: Know the change in the nucleus that occurs during B-emission: neutron → proton + electron

B4D778638FE047D08D7F27A9D1DBAFD8.description: Know that during α-decay or ß-decay, the nucleus changes to that of a different element

D0BE12FB432C4FB290DC0C3B5E67AE67.description: Know that radioactive decay is a change in an unstable nucleus that can result in the emission of α-particles or B-particles and/or γ-radiation and know that these changes are spontaneous and random

EFDCF57E00B14CD8ADB629E28C2BF824.description: their relative penetrating abilities (B+ are not included, B particles will be taken to refer to B-)

IpVp=IsVs
 where p and s refer to primary and secondary

Recall and use the equation:
Vp/Vs = Np/Ns

7EBA240468BE40F18D8FD2649EA01071.description: the total p.d. across the components in a series circuit is equal to the sum of the individual p.d.s across each component

Recall and use the equation for electrical power 
P = IV

Recall and use the equation for resistance:
R = V/I

6473B8D3183A443CB8F5C3FC69626081.description: Know that the p.d. between two points is measured in volts (V)

591F87F1F3AB4B7785013A57E79D2956.description: Define potential difference (p.d.) as the work done by a unit charge passing between two points in a circuit

9EAE57BA48AA4C9BBFA6A68B6DF0EC5C.description: Define electromotive force (e.m.f.) as the electrical work done by a source in moving a unit charge around a complete circuit

8F6F5160481747C793858A2A43E4DBFA.description: Know that the voltage of the source is shared between the components in a series circuit

8A911AB6A9864305A0197D02BBB94A6E.description: Describe the voltage of the source as the cause of current in the circuit

8D654077F617495E915D67D7C262CF6A.description: State that conventional current is from positive to negative and that the flow of electrons is from negative to positive

E9C576C5B74E4C638BE5B2B9B3F75183.description: Describe electrical conduction in metals in terms of the movement of delocalised (mobile) electrons

FD34EC22AC614C3992898C191797CF19.description:
Define electric current as the charge passing a point per unit time; recall and use the equation:
I = Q/
t

0AC0641AB3A1402FBA11980EC416479B.description: Know that electric current is related to the flow of charge

8DA081F0676249E295ADDF5DD288A466.description: State that charge is measured in coulombs

6A5FEB9D8EEF41B6B8C3FC16E4621228.description: Know that charging of solids by friction involves only a transfer of negative charge (electrons)

E399E627692E4B7FB2A1A2FC5610455A.description: Describe electrostatic charging by friction, and simple methods to determine if an object is charged

51E70C265522410085652120357F8C63.description: State that positive charges repel other positive charges, negative charges repel other negative charges, but positive charges attract negative charges

F19421D8DD044983B2608B2701B34434.description: State that there are positive and negative charges

1FC3B6D1736449B99EC0F9542AE51761.description: State that the direction of a magnetic field at a point is the direction of the force on the N pole of a magnet at that point

EE05EFD253FD4BC092D528D53C2FAD87.description: Describe a magnetic field as a region in which a magnetic pole experiences a force

0C144BAB1CC3445482CB2BDCB6E06014.description: Describe how a permanent magnet differs trom an electromagnet

1906E8D0B3D34DD38880C2F7FD052F6B.description: Describe the forces between magnetic poles and between magnets and magnetic materials, including the use of the terms north pole (N pole) and south pole (S pole), attraction and repulsion, magnetised and unmagnetised

83089014D71749A78F3E57E8115E8296.description: X-rays and gamma rays; mutation or damage to cells in the body

0AA0DEE29B2F453E8697FEC20EEA6436.description: ultraviolet; damage to surface cells and eyes, leading to skin cancer and eye conditions

5D5C7C32D80F4DA19CA244C17FED4B09.description: Describe the harmful effects on people of excessive exposure to electromagnetic radiation, including:

D472B161E20F4EBDBA154620B852E951.description: infrared; remote controllers for televisions, thermal imaging

E775CF02A5754EAFB51CD007D141918D.description: microwaves; satellite television, mobile (cell) phone, microwave ovens

459E01A98EE34E0F8FABE7332C6350EB.description: radio waves; radio and television transmissions, radar

Recall and use the equation:
n = sin i / sin r

7714EDC2148446CD89CA4F822845B010.description: retraction due to a change of speed

C15E62A5B2B043C6AE5866793E2FE9A6.description: Know that waves transfer energy without transferring matter

9C551FF60C9944A4B1F9A2258C4F0667.description: Describe how temperature, surface area and air movement over a surface affect evaporation

8BF1286BFDBE4139BFE9C9E6A114921D.description: Know the melting and boiling temperatures for water at standard atmospheric pressure (limited to Celsius only)

99BED1207762424CB3F914C98FB8139A.description: a change of temperature at constant volume

E3AF926FDF594E6E8C15AB3EE8B99ACC.description: Describe the pressure of a gas in terms of the forces exerted by particles colliding with surfaces, creating a force per unit area

B66419642D4D45EDB1E41D23B33C34FA.description: Describe and explain this motion (sometimes known as Brownian motion) in terms of random collisions between particles in the suspension and the much smaller, fastmoving particles of the gas or liquid

F572C02305A641E0862AFEBA8BDA736D.description: Know that the forces and distances between particles and the motion of the particles affect the properties of solids, liquids and gases

5DFD15C86897406584F9E8855CE24D3C.description: Know that the random motion of particles (e.g. smoke particles or pollen grains, that can be viewed with a light microscope) in a suspension is evidence for the kinetic particle model of matter

976A5111D3D5453DB70DB9C97F577F0D.description: Describe the relationship between the motion of particles and temperature

EE24242EBACF4A0BA488F0DBDCD98453.description: Describe the structure of solids, liquids and gases in terms of the arrangement, separation and motion of the particles and represent these states using simple particle diagrams

7302879A68F044C6B3E397285400E5C8.description: Know the terms for the changes in state between solids, liquids and gases (gas to solid and solid to gas changes are not required)

4044ACAFECDD4C06B3CE3BDC60C45AB7.description: State the distinguishing properties of solids, liquids and gases

02F821CC02154A249B82B64066512E5F.description:
Define pressure as force per unit area; recall and use the equation:
p = F/A

BEEE84A8580E4653BB09F545720AB62E.description: Describe how pressure varies with force and area in the context of everyday examples

DDDF7B6DB92D4D07B80E9B7E18F94A8C.description: Define power as work done per unit time and also as energy transferred per unit time; recall and use the equations

D288D21D819A494C8483EAE6350CDCFF.description: efficiency = useful power output / useful power input x 100% recall and use the equations

131EEA4B63B64538B86C25A8CFF75836.description: efficiency = useful energy output / useful energy input x 100%

BE53441357C34F8F88DAE597DF484EC8.description: Know that energy is released by nuclear fission in nuclear reactors (detailed knowledge of the process of fission is not required)

8FFBB82D47FC4D268E9A2D68D6B4F13D.description: Know that energy is released by nuclear fusion in the Sun (detailed knowledge of the process of fusion is not required)

699A946A9A0A45DF877C47444BA11061.description: Know that radiation from the Sun is the main source of energy for all our energy resources except geothermal, nuclear and tidal

F6938A27A5C043598FF5287E78AE0160.description: Understand, qualitatively, the concept of efficiency of energy transfer

1416C44B1ED44282ABBE8C674408F96B.description: Give advantages and disadvantages of each method in terms of renewability, availability, reliability, scale and environmental impact

783CE21B0D7D4D9CAE7BB33D957243CE.description:
wind (wind turbines) 
including references to a boiler, turbine and generator where they are used

98274E47D75848708689F7B2A75C0F6A.description: infrared and other electromagnetic waves from the Sun to heat water (solar thermal collectors

ACAA1DFCBB074CBB9DAFD1CD2303AB1F.description: water, including waves, tides, and hydroelectric dams

FFB50CA6A2E243E88500033D5AFBA6FE.description: Describe how useful energy may be obtained, or electrical power generated, from:

B3D236C5E5814430A38266A978B07DEA.description:
Recall and use the equation for mechanical working:
W = Fd = ΔE

6730EFACD61549D5A69802FDE3594327.description: Understand that mechanical or electrical work done is equal to the energy transferred

3EC369C17AE54350821DD7B9539D68AE.description:
Recall and use the equation for the change in gravitational potential energy:
ΔEp = mΔgh

720C612984A448DC8F160058B875162A.description:
Recall and use the equation for kinetic energy:
Ek = 1/2 mv^2

2492E920F6DB4537BD09799CCBF5B1EA.description: Know the principle of conservation of energy and apply this principle to simple examples including the interpretation of simple flow diagrams (Sankey diagrams are not required)

D7B96701B1694B9A8D68F5DB5A1C2623.description: Describe how energy is transferred between stores during events and processes, including examples of transfer by forces (mechanical work done), electrical currents (electrical work done), heating and by electromagnetic, sound and other waves

663EB79737534DB78D0983E64B4AAA13.description: State that energy may be stored as kinetic, gravitational potential, chemical, elastic (strain), nuclear, electrostatic and internal (thermal)

1208DF3352FC45959DECD4147A58A4F4.description: Describe, qualitatively, the effect of the position of the centre of gravity on the stability of simple objects

E0EE8CE880994F7A81F3F90C26DBCC20.description: Describe an experiment to determine the position of the centre of gravity of an irregularly shaped plane lamina

D19695EB36F24EDEB43BCC62FD2BF34C.description: Understand what is meant by centre of gravity and know its position for regularly shaped objects (limited to rectangular blocks, spheres and cylinders)

9620D94B19EF4DE5AD3857B80E11F176.description: Apply the principle of moments to situations with one force each side of the pivot, including balancing of a beam

7CA932C49DB1432E94B11A11B049FC4B.description: State that, when there is no resultant force and no resultant moment, an object is in equilibrium

626A854325744DDA955841F3C7D4A517.description: Define the moment of a force as moment = force x perpendicular distance from the pivot; recall and use this equation

D2BB0E058D3D4306A9ECF2A459A45A27.description: Describe the moment of a force as a measure of its turning effect and give everyday examples

F145C3D9B44C4B969C9CE23BB7866221.description: Define and use the term 'limit of proportionality' for a load-extension graph and identify this point on the graph (an understanding of the elastic limit is not required)

49AE0D7658EC480589512C5684A564AF.description:
Define the spring constant as force per unit extension; recall and use the equation:
k = F / x

F7D8897D919A418F821AB744BA9E8C3C.description: Sketch, plot and interpret load-extension graphs for an elastic solid and describe the associated experimental procedures

2CE891E3399A4D14B040BBD1FD335918.description: Recall and use the equation F = ma and know that the resultant force and the acceleration are in the same direction

2EB186555C09407BB60FDD75187CA306.description: Know that an object either remains at rest or continues in a straight line at constant speed unless there is a resultant force on the object

9D657A981107499392F1DD4476BEB481.description: Know that friction (drag) acts on an object moving through a gas (e.g. air resistance)

50FE741CC7BB494F8CEBAD87E269E655.description: Know that friction (drag) acts on an object moving through a liquid

CA767449FD9A4A0997EDD8F7EDAF05D5.description: Determine the resultant of two or more forces acting along the same straight line

4F37425CAA8444EF930AF598971C21DA.description: Know that forces may produce changes in the size, shape and motion of an object

2CB64809F48F42758489A7F340383A21.description: Determine whether an object floats or sinks based on density data

9CD0DDE7C1E049F48117C7D6614F869E.description: Describe how to determine the density of a liquid, of a regularly shaped solid and of an irregularly shaped solid which sinks in a liquid (volume by displacement), including appropriate calculations

48944CB6648B4C1B86661337CE85D39C.description:
Define density as mass per unit volume; recall and use the equation:
p = m / v

08C86D5CAD214E2388A25D694426EAA4.description: Know that gravitational field strength is equivalent to the acceleration of free fall

A44AECDE1BC14150B99D698F20954655.description: Describe, and use the concept of, weight as the effect of a gravitational field on a mass

1BDE3FD6006F4B3EB96BFF2EC41FB970.description:
Define gravitational field strength g as the gravitational force per unit mass; recall and use the equation
g = W / m
and know that near to the surface of the Earth, g is approximately 9.8 N/kg

(a) constant acceleration 
(b) changing acceleration

a =Δv/Δt

FD71295D07D14F97A13689653F5903A9.description: Sketch, plot and interpret distance-time and speed-time graphs

FBA2E7B6611E4119938ECF414493BFAA.description: Recall and use the equation: average speed = total distance travelled/total time taken

E5BE943B50974B0DAB6A804F3583D30F.description: Define speed as distance travelled per unit time; recall and use the equation: v = s/t

49179EA6479643E5B1964614A1C47139.description: Know that the following quantities are vectors: force, weight, velocity, acceleration and gravitational field strength

4787C3E68ED84F7695E4E80A4494570E.description: Know that the following quantities are scalars: distance, speed, time, mass, energy and temperature

CD7D29AD380642B18CB7F1C638AFFC2E.description: Understand that a scalar quantity has magnitude (size) only and that a vector quantity has magnitude and direction

7592F8AE39CE479385F21C5BE96A190C.description: Determine an average value for a small distance and for a short interval of time by measuring multiples (including the period of oscillation of a pendulum)

68526DEC1FA0444AACE6E9D0E98204D7.description: Describe how to measure a variety of time intervals using clocks and digital timers

6A8794F336B04C34B5A9F376BD0F8A1C.description: Describe the use of rulers and measuring cylinders to find a length or a volume
